title: 113_hr4831
content: The Act titled "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014" allows for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Secretary of the Treasury will make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches for trainees. Eligible community colleges are public institutions offering 2-year associate's degrees accepted for credit towards a bachelor's degree. Higher education institutions offering 2-year associate's degrees accepted for credit towards a bachelor's degree can participate in a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program. This program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for tax credits on State income taxes withheld for eligible trainees once employed. The program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for tax credits on State income taxes withheld for eligible trainees once employed. The withheld taxes will be remitted to the community college for education provided, and will be treated as payment for income taxes owed by the trainee. The program allows eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for tax credits on State income taxes withheld for eligible trainees once employed. The contract must meet specific requirements, including direct provision of qualified training by the community college to designated individuals. The State program allows eligible community colleges to provide qualified training to individuals designated by employers, who will then hire them for full-time employment at a job site within the State. The individuals must be paid a wage that is at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the amount specified under the State program, and the community college cannot charge tuition or fees to the individuals. The State program allows community colleges to provide qualified training to individuals designated by employers, who must be paid a wage of at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the State program amount. Employers must remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of individuals to the community college for training costs specified in the contract. The training cost and terms must be reasonable by market standards. Qualified training provided under the State program must be reasonable by market standards and includes education or skills necessary for the job, obtaining required licenses, or certifications mandated by regulations. The State program requires individuals to have necessary certificates or credentials for the job, aligned with industry standards. The program also mandates that eligible trainees must be hired for new jobs to qualify for the tax credit. The program requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs that result in a net increase in employment for the employer. The job must not be a recalled worker, replacement job, or a job that existed in the employer's business within the previous year. Additionally, the job must not have existed in a business operation of the employer formerly located in another location that was closed or substantially reduced. Only U.S. employees are taken into account for the tax credit. The program requires eligible trainees to be hired for new jobs that result in a net increase in employment for the employer. Only U.S. employees at job sites in the United States are considered for the tax credit. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code are treated as a single employer for this program. Employers participating in a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program may collaborate with local workforce investment boards. The program allows employers to collaborate with local workforce investment boards to hire and train eligible individuals through a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program. Eligible trainees must receive qualified training from a community college and be employed full-time by the employer in the same state as the college. The manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible manufacturing employers to hire individuals for full-time jobs at a wage that meets requirements, in a job that requires qualified training, and is located in the same state as the community college providing the training. Eligible employers must be engaged in manufacturing in the United States. The manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible manufacturing employers to hire individuals for full-time jobs at a wage that meets requirements, in a job that requires qualified training, and is located in the same state as the community college providing the training. Eligible employers must be engaged in manufacturing in the United States and fall under sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the North American Industrial Classification System. Appropriation of necessary funds is provided for the implementation of this program. Remission of State Income Tax Withholdings for training is not considered as payments for training or education. Tax treatment of payments with respect to eligible trainees is also outlined. The employer's payments for eligible trainees are not considered income for the trainee under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts withheld for State income tax and payments made to eligible community colleges are treated as payments for State income taxes by the trainee for tax deduction purposes.
